content.description:
“The philosophy of the eighteenth century takes up . . . the methodological pattern of Newton’s physics, though it immediately begins to generalize from it. It is not content to look upon analysis as the great intellectual tool of mathematical and physical knowledge; eighteenth-century thought sees analysis rather as the necessary and indispensable instrument of all thinking in general. This view triumphs in the middle of the [eighteenth] century. However much individual thinkers and schools differed in their results, they agreed in this methodological premise.”
Ernst Cassirer, German historian, The Philosophy of the Enlightenment, 1932
content.question: The worldview described in the passage became dominant most likely as a result of which of the following developments?

choices.label: The spread of printed materials that popularized the ideas of the Enlightenment
The continued reliance on classical Greek and Roman texts as sources of knowledge
The revival of Protestant and Catholic religious faith during the eighteenth century
The prevalence of absolutism forms of monarchy in much of Europe

content.answer: The spread of printed materials that popularized the ideas of the Enlightenment
